keyTakeAways: Cancer does not discriminate politically, enabling patients and survivors to transcend partisan divides when advocating for public health policies.
Despite deep political polarization, bipartisan support exists for funding cancer research, expanding cancer screening, and maintaining health insurance subsidies.
Volunteers from diverse political backgrounds united around a shared personal experience with cancer, demonstrating the power of shared trauma in fostering political empathy.
The event included over 500 volunteers, with 484 congressional offices visited, emphasizing the scale and reach of grassroots advocacy.
A candlelight vigil on the National Mall memorialized 10,000 individuals affected by cancer, symbolizing the human cost of the disease and the collective effort to address it.

summaryOfNewsArticle: In the midst of a federal government shutdown, over 500 cancer survivors and advocates from across the U.S., including individuals from New York such as Mary Catherine Johnson, Lexy Mealing, and Katie Martin, organized a bipartisan citizen lobbying effort in Washington, D.C. Despite their diverse political affiliations — Johnson voted for Donald Trump three times, Mealing is a Democrat, and Martin did not discuss her politics — all shared a personal experience with cancer. The event, organized by the American Cancer Society Cancer Action Network, focused on urging Congress to increase cancer research funding, expand access to cancer screening, and retain health insurance subsidies. Volunteers visited 484 congressional offices, demonstrating that shared personal trauma can transcend political differences. A candlelight vigil on the National Mall memorialized 10,000 individuals affected by cancer. The article highlights the power of personal experience to foster empathy, and underscores a broad public consensus that cancer-related policies are a priority across party lines, even as national politics remain deeply divided.
title: 'Cancer doesn't care': Patients pushed past divisive politics to lobby Congress
